hypotheses.prediction: IF primary human hepatocytes are stratified by baseline GSH/GSSG ratio into tertiles (low <30, mid 30-60, high >60), THEN low-tertile cells treated with CBD (10 µM, 48h) will show ≥2.5-fold greater LDH release and ≥3-fold greater ALT leakage compared to high-tertile cells, with AUC for GSH/GSSG predicting >20% cell death of 0.65-0.75.
hypotheses.experimental_protocol: Obtain cryopreserved primary human hepatocytes from ≥20 donors (BioIVT/Lonza). Measure baseline GSH/GSSG (enzymatic recycling assay). Treat with CBD (1, 5, 10, 25, 50 µM) ± valproate (300 µM) for 24/48/72h.
hypotheses.expected_outcome: Monotonic inverse relationship between baseline GSH/GSSG and hepatocyte death; ROC AUC 0.65-0.75; ketoconazole partially but not fully rescues toxicity in low-GSH donors, confirming dual mechanism.
hypotheses.null_outcome: No correlation between GSH/GSSG and cell death (AUC <0.55), or ketoconazole fully rescues toxicity (implicating CYP450 only, not VDAC-mediated oxidative stress).

hypotheses.prediction: IF VDAC1 is knocked down (siRNA, >70% reduction) in HepG2 cells, THEN CBD-induced (10 µM, 48h) ROS production will decrease by ≥40% and cell death by ≥50%, whereas CYP3A4 activity inhibition by CBD will remain unchanged (±10%).
hypotheses.experimental_protocol: Transfect HepG2 cells with VDAC1 siRNA (3 sequences) or scrambled control (48h knockdown confirmed by qPCR/Western). Treat with CBD (1, 5, 10, 25 µM) for 24/48h. Parallel VDAC1-overexpression arm (pcDNA3-VDAC1). Measure all
hypotheses.expected_outcome: VDAC1 KD significantly reduces ROS and cell death without altering CYP3A4 inhibition by CBD; VDAC1 overexpression sensitizes cells. VDAC2 KD shows smaller or no effect. This mechanistically separates VDAC-mediated oxidative toxicity from CYP-mediated metabolic toxicity.
hypotheses.null_outcome: VDAC1 KD does not reduce CBD toxicity (≤15% change), or VDAC1 KD also reduces CYP3A4 inhibition proportionally (suggesting confounded pathway, not independent mechanism).

hypotheses.prediction: IF hepatocytes are exposed to escalating doses of CBD or erastin, THEN the three-component panel (GSH, ATP/ADP, MMP) will show coordinated dose-dependent deterioration with ≥0.85 Spearman correlation between composite panel score and subsequent cell death (measured 24h later), and the panel at 6h will predict 48h toxicity with AUC ≥0.80.
hypotheses.experimental_protocol: Use primary human hepatocytes (≥10 donors) and HepaRG cells. Treat with CBD (1-50 µM) or erastin (1-20 µM) or acetaminophen (1-20 mM). Measure panel at 2, 6, 12, 24h. Measure cell death at 24, 48, 72h. Build composite score (weighted PCA of 3 metrics). Test whether 6h panel predicts 48h death. Include TRPV1 agonist capsaicin (10 µM) and TRPV1 antagonist AMG9810 (3 µM) + CBD arm to test confounding by non-mitochondrial CBD targets. Timeline: 10 weeks.
hypotheses.null_outcome: Panel components change non-concordantly or show poor predictive power (AUC <0.65); or capsaicin alone significantly alters panel metrics, indicating TRPV1-mediated confounding that undermines diagnostic specificity.
controls: Complex I inhibition as non-VDAC mitochondrial toxicant)

hypotheses.prediction: IF a panel of cancer cell lines (n≥15) is ranked by VDAC1 protein expression, THEN VDAC1-high lines (top quartile) will show ≥3-fold lower IC50 for erastin and ≥2-fold lower IC50 for CBD compared to VDAC1-low lines (bottom quartile), with VDAC1 expression explaining ≥30% of variance in drug sensitivity (R² ≥0.30).
